subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: On Wed, 05 Jan 2005 09:59:19 -0800, Kevin Lawrence ... Right, and if the code in question were particularly long, or ugly in some other fashion, I d agree.
messageBody:
On Wed, 05 Jan 2005 09:59:19 -0800, Kevin Lawrence
<kevin@...> wrote:
> The standard answer is that comments are a way to deodorize a code smell
> and that you can often make the smell go away rather than cover it up
> with a comment. Of course, this isn't always possible and sometimes not
> even desirable in a test.

Right, and if the code in question were particularly long, or ugly in
some other fashion, I'd agree. Taken alone your kind of comments can
sound suspiciously like "my code is self-documenting". And it isn't.

>
> Sometimes it is though. I find that when I have a lot of page long
> tests, there is a lot of duplication between the tests - which hurts
> maintainability and readability. EXTRACT METHOD can help with both.
>
> I am imagining something like this :
>
> public void testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForOneSalesOrderLine()
> {
> createSalesOrderLine(...);
> addCustomerPurchaseOrder( .... X );
> addCustomerPurchaseOrder( .... Y );
> assertSomethingAboutOrders( ...expected ...);
> }
>
> Any chance we can see the test ?

You've described pretty much what it does. There is other set-up that
is done in this test that isn't done in the other tests in order to
create the many purchase order situation, and there are more
assertions because it checks a larger (about fifteen) set of data
going in and out. Most of that is done by helper methods, but you
have to record the values, so there's a lot of things like:

String customerPO = "somenumber";
String housebillNumber = "someHawb";
String somethingElseToBeCheckedLater = "somevalue";

and their accompanying assert clauses. Yes, I could do these in a
separate test, an interesting refactor and something we'd likely do in
a code review, but not something I did the first time, and not the
source of the complexity that required the comment.

I'd share the test, but it uses client-specific data. Some of it I
could change, but some values and paradigms are expected by the rest
of the system (client codes, account nubmers, etc).

In general, what I wanted to say was that while Mike's right that most
of the time the method name is sufficient, sometimes the case is
enough of a corner that you both need and want a short description of
what the heck is going on. Not shipping any javadoc is turning that
'sometimes' into 'never'.

-Kevin
